conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area on a surface. The position and size depend on the positions of the light source, object, and surface.
There are four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D. The light source is positioned to cast these shadows on the ground.
When the light source moves backward, the angle of light changes, shadows become longer, and their position shifts forward.
Shadow A will elongate and move forward on the ground as the light source moves backward.
Shadow B will elongate and move forward, with elongation depending on the object's height and shape.
Shadow C will experience significant elongation and forward movement, possibly becoming more diffuse.
Shadow D will elongate and move forward, with a noticeable size increase if the object is tall.
As the light source moves backward, shadows A, B, C, and D will elongate and move forward on the ground.
